overview_of_class:
SPEAKING and UNDERSTANDING the way Arabs/Egyptians speak in everyday life is a major goal of this course. In this course students will intensively practice speaking and master using colloquial Arabic for everyday oral communication. They will learn about the intricacies of diglossic sociolinguistic situations through the specific example of Egypt. Students will become familiar with important cultural themes in Arab/ Egyptian society which inform individual and collective behavior. Students will learn to analyze similarities and differences between formal, written "Modern Standard Arabic" and the spoken regional Egyptian variety. They will also gain valuable insight into Egyptian and Arab language and culture, laying important groundwork for more successful "Study Abroad" or work abroad experiences. 

Although the focus of this course is building verbal and conversation skills of the students in Egyptian Arabic, a "contrastive analysis" and "comparative dialectology " between spoken Arabic and MSA will be discussed in a systematic way. The main spoken dialects used in this comparative are the most widespread dialects in the Arab world; the Egyptian and the Levantine.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Students should listen to the CD conversations prior to coming to class. The class starts with discussing vocabulary, idioms and expressions based on student questions. Students are asked to use what they learnt in a context (short dialogs). Students practice conversation in class in twos. Instructor evaluates and corrects the conversation. Contrastive analysis with Fusha is discussed and explained. Class presentations should implement and reflect the students' knowledge of the Egyptian and Arab society to some degree.

Cultural analysis and debates will address sociopolitical conditions in Egypt and the Arab world. It will include issues such as democracy, impact of the internet on the Arab collective awareness, women liberation movements and feminism, tradition and modernity in Egypt, the view of America in the eyes of the public in Egypt, the modern Egyptian song and music and the Cinema of Youssef Shaheen. Basic presentations about the cultural and natural heritage of Egypt will be presented in class by the instructor and the students.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
20 % Attendance and participation.
10 % Assignments and quizzes.
10% Oral presentations.
10% Class project.
25% Midterm exam (written and oral).
25% Final exam (written and oral).
Class project:

This could be done as an individual project or a group one. In the previous years, students wrote a script for a short play and presented it in class after a series of rehearsals. Some students may prefer to work on an individual project that focuses on a comparative dialect or a cultural theme of their interest.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required Text: Learn Arabic the Fast and Fun Way by Ibrahim, Ragy H. (2008) Paperback. Publisher: Barron's Educational Series ASIN: B00RKQPTR6

Optional: Dardasha: Let's Speak Egyptian Arabic : A Multidimensional Approach to the Teaching and Learning of Egyptian Arabic As a Foreign Language. Publisher: Natl African Languages Resource Ctr; illustrated edition (January 2004) ISBN-10: 0967958784 ISBN-13: 978-0967958781

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
a- Listening skills ( e.g. watching  interviews within Egyptian programs /, TV series/soap operas, films, songs...).

b- Examining how literature integrates and represents the diglossic situation in different genre ( e.g. short stories, newspaper columnists, plays, bloggers sites, Friday prayers sermons, ...)

c- Comparative dialectology with MSA and discussing the cultural contexts and backgrounds through the materials used in class with the students.
